TopicTitle: The Venturer Program: Tour of the planets

Articles.Content:
Hmmmm....

Not warp drive, but the next best thing.

CHAPTER 62: Ã¢â‚¬Â¦TWO STEPS FORWARD

CaptainÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s log, entry 88: Well, things are looking up, I guess. After getting the long range comms back up and running a few weeks back, we managed to get in touch with control, as IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve mentioned inÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ well, one of these damned logs, somewhere. Anyway, long story short, the technical expertise they provided was outstandingly useful and we got these conversions done a couple of weeks faster than Lengas had originally anticipated. Now we just need to test the bloody things and hope they donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t kill us when we turn them on.

Bill said heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s been working on the Eeloo transfer trajectory. No less than a 5 year journey (but no more than 7 years, mind youÃ¢â‚¬Â¦)Ã¢â‚¬Â¦ All I could say to that was thank frakking Kod I came up with this idea when I did.

Other than that, wellÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ nothing much happened. I guess itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s probably important to mention that weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve all spoken to our families now that our comms work again. Kod, that wasÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ I canÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t express what I felt when I saw my wifeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s face on that screen. Her eyes, her voiceÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ damn it, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m getting teary-eyed just thinking about it. I know I chose to come out on this mission, but in hindsight, was it really such a good idea? Damn itÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

A few hours laterÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Cease burn.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Cutting engines. HowÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re we looking?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“One trajectory change once weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re out of DunaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s SOI should be enough to get us where we want.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Good. How long until that burn?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ooh, uhÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ a few days?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alright. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m gonna tell control that weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re heading out again.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok. Say, have we tested those things in the back, yet?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Later today. Lengas is just making sure everything is comfortable and that we wonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t all wind up with freezerburn.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ouch, freezerburn, not nice. I knew a guy once who had that happen to his hand in a cryogenics lab. WasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t good.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well letÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s just hope that doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t happen here.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb hits a few buttons at a console behind his pilot seat.

KSC: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Enterprise?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yep, who else?Ã¢â‚¬Â

KSC: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey Jeb, whatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s up? Nothing bad with those cryopods, I hope?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No, no, weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re testing them later. Listen, weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve just made the burn. One more and weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be heading for Eeloo.Ã¢â‚¬Â

KSC: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Roger that, Jeb. Damn, just Eeloo left, now. Seems like only yesterday that you left.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Believe me, it doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t feel like that for us at all.Ã¢â‚¬Â

KSC: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I suppose not. Still, just one more planet and youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re home-free. We all wish you luck down here. Safe journey. Control out.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm, nice and abrupt.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, I suppose theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve got a fair amount going on back at Kerbin aside from just our mission, as huge as our mission actually has been.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“TrueÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You alright?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s justÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ if these pods work, weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll have essentially just two more weeks of conscious flight time and then itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be all over.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That it will.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re so tantalisingly close to the endÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ but then thereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s the point that while everyone at home ages, we wonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t. WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll still be our current age in 6 yearsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ time.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, thereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s that, I guess, but in all honesty, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s probably a small price to pay.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I wouldnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t precisely call it small, Bill.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“So sue me.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Heh.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Seriously though, if thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a concern, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m sure thereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a way we can make a compromise on this whole cryostasis business.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“HmmÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ we could have a day or two here and there being out of cryo so we could catch up with home. ThereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s no sense in fixing the long range comms and not using it. It doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t really circumvent the non-aging process, though.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Perhaps not, but it seems like a decent deal. At least that way your folks will be able to talk to you more often.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“YeahÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ alright, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m gonna have to mull this over on my own for a bit. You know where to find me.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Sure thing.Ã¢â‚¬Â

A few days laterÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

-----

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“My micromanagement processes are currently operating with a 92% efficiency, but I will do my best to maintain every single cryopod while you all sleep. Given my recent condition, however, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d feel a lot more comfortable if it were only my micromanagement systems enabled lest I accidentally damage some hardware. Or software.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Wait, you can go into a low functionality state?Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yes. However, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d need restarting if full functionality were to be restored.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“HmmÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Jeb, are you coming orÃ¢â‚¬Â¦?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Just give me a few minutes, Bob.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alright. Listen, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m going under, now. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll see you if I wake up.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“WhatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s this Ã¢â‚¬ËœifÃ¢â‚¬â„¢? You should say Ã¢â‚¬ËœwhenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢, instead.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I should. I would. But unproven technology made out of converted refrigerators? I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t know.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, you worked on them with Lengas, so surely you know what youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re dealing with?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, I know what IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m dealing with. I guess itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s just the thought of it, you know.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢sÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ odd. Anyway, if you want to go under, then go under. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll see you on the other side, maybe even in between if we get woken up at the same time along this flight.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“YeahÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ well, lights out.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob clambers into his pod before the door seals him in.

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm, I guess itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s just you and me for a bit, Stanley.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Not quite.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Eh?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m still here, Jeb.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“AH, geez! DonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t do that, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m too old!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Sorry, I didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t think IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d startle you.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I thought youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d gone into a pod, youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been that quiet.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, well, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve just been thinking, really.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“AboutÃ¢â‚¬Â¦?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I know I built those things, but I sure as hell am not using them.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“What? Why?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, for a start, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m not entirely sure using old core sample fridges as stasis chambers is exactly a good idea, and while the conversion went well enough, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m still wary of some of the things. Secondly, well, someone needs to keep an eye on the ship while youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re asleep.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“We have Stanley for that, though.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“And even Stanley himself says that he doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t want to risk glitches, so IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m gonna keep him in a good way. Plus, that reactor if left aloneÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“But wonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t it be weird, eh? WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll all be staying our age and youÃ¢â‚¬â€Ã¢â‚¬Å“

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yes, I know, but honestly, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d much rather be the same age as IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m supposed to be when I get home to my family.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ah, now thereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s something I thought of, too.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve all thought it, Jeb. Every single one of us.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“UnderstandablyÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“The point is, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m not going into that dreamless sleep.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“If thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s what you want.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It is.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alright. JustÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ I might stay up for a few more hours. Stare at Duna. The stars. Maybe talk to my family before I freeze.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll stick around with you, then.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thanks.Ã¢â‚¬Â

A pause for a moment.

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s oddly quiet, with that lot in there. Not even snoring or sleep-talking, justÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ silence.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s about the most quiet IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve had for a long time.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“YouÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re about to have a lot more where that came from, too.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, I guess I am.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Here's hoping Lengas doesn't lose it from the semi-isolation. Maybe chat with Control regularly?

Gud werk, comrade.

Oh my goodness.

Methinks I need to catch up. Big time.

CHAPTER 63: FINAL FRONTIER

Chief Engineer/GeologistÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s log, entry 101: TheyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re asleep. TheyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re all asleep. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m alone. Not lonely, butÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ alone. Odd. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s really quiet save for the purr of the ship and its systems ticking over. At my request, though, Stanley has decided to remain in full operation mode with the assurance that IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d be around to maintain anything he breaks. Huh, I keep calling Stanley a Ã¢â‚¬ËœheÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ or a Ã¢â‚¬ËœhimÃ¢â‚¬â„¢. I guess when you spend so long with so convincing an AI, you sort of justÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ fall into that habit.

Anyway, shipÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s fine for now. I ran a triple diagnostic on the cryopods along with the reactor and nothingÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s wrong. Reactor efficiency dropped off to 94%, but I can fix that in a few hours. For now, though, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m going to get something to eat. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve got the entirety of the stores to choose from.

-----

Chief Engineer/GeologistÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s log, entry 102: Two weeks since leaving DunaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s SOI, one since the guys went under, and nothing has gone wrong, thankfully. I had to clean out a few air filters, one involving a toothpick and some very creatively used socks, so now the air is feeling quite fresh. Not as good as in the greenhouses, but still better than a lot of places on Kerbin. I suppose thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d have to be the case, though.

As for myself, well, I feel fine. StanleyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s good company. Sure itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s odd knowing that theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re all back there in those pods, just doing nothing, but IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m fine. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve taken to reading up on some celestial mechanics. Got through the basics of orbital mechanics, and even though I can fly ships, there was some very handy stuff in those texts. Interesting, even. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve just got to reading more about the subtle gravitational interactions over huge distances. No better way to spend my time at the moment, and it certainly makes time fly quite nicely.

-----

Chief Engineer/GeologistÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s log, entry 103: A fortnight since the freezing. Nothing out of the ordinary. Went on EVA to maintain some solar cells, thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s about it for my work. Got through all that gravitational nuances stuff, so now IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m reading stuff on wormholes and relativity. I sort of knew about time dilation already, but this stuff is justÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ damn. Gotta respect the physicists with doctorates to their names.

-----

Chief Engineer/GeologistÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s log, entry 104: Two months since the freezing. Had a bit of a drama with a bowl of cereal escaping into the ventilation shafts, but after chasing down a rogue corn loop, I cleaned everything up. Nothing damaged. Stanley even helped confine the renegade breakfast. Unfortunately, everything smells of slightly souring milk, now. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll get some air freshener sorted.

Wormholes are sweet, by the way. Started working on a simulation on the computers. Messed up the code first time round and nearly fried the CPU, but this second bit of software IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m working on looks to be fine so far.

-----

Chief Engineer/GeologistÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s log, entry 105: I decided to contact home today. To say they were surprised that I was up and about would be an understatement. Naturally, my Jhen came and spoke to me, daft girl. Damn I love her so much. Makes me think of using one of those pods myself so I can see her sooner, so to speak.

Control apparently had a bit of an accident involving one of the refuelling stations and the Libra. Libra didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t slow down enough and smacked into the truss. Lost two solar panels whilst knocking off a docking port from the station, not to mention weakening the truss structure. No-one was hurt, and no-oneÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s been blamed for it, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been led to believe. ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s good.

Oh, my wormhole simulation works! I can input parameters, variables and whatnot to change the characteristics, and itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s all based on every scrap of theoretical and hypothetical work I could find, so what IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m seeing on the screen is what a wormhole should actually look like! ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s pretty frakking sweet, if you ask me!

Engineer, geologistÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ who knows, maybe astrophysics is in my future? IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be talking with Cal, I thinkÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

-----

Chief Engineer/GeologistÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s log, entry 106: I, uh, sort of havenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t written any logs for a few months. UhÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ 7 and a half months since the last one. Whoops. Anyway, a scheduled intermission in the cryostasis was enacted as authorised by Jeb and everyone came out for a few days to catch up. At that point, weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d just crossed DresÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ orbital path. They all contacted home, had a laugh with each other (myself included), and then after 4 days, they went back in the pods without a hitch. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be honest, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s getting a little tempting to use one of those; they seem to work fine. Fear of the unknown, I guess, though if that were true, then what am I doing all the way out here? Why did I sign up for Odysseus way back when? Not fear of the unknown, it would seem.

Started reading about black holes. ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s some crazy stuff. White holes, should they exist, are even stranger. Might need to go back to reading childrenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s books for a bit just to stop my head from hurting with all this information.

-----

Chief Engineer/GeologistÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s log, entry 107: Today was not a good day. Stanley had a glitch that nearly wiped out the control systems for the fusion core. Naturally, when the alarms went off, I sort of panicked. Woke everyone up, got them in the landers and the bridge and told them to stay put until I could see what was wrong. Bob helped me out, thankfully, even as groggy as he was. Sure enough, some of the electromagnets were varying their power levels wildly and it was destabilising the plasma torus. I suited up while Bob tried to manually regain control, which he did long enough for me to replace some now-ruined circuit boards. Took an hour, tops, given that I was sort of rushing to save the ship from an impending thermonuclear explosion. Frakking hell, that was stressful. Everyone is back in the pods, now, next scheduled intermission in 3 months.

Until then, more black holes.

-----

Chief Engineer/GeologistÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s log, entry 108: So, my last log was 4 months ago. The crew had their second scheduled intermission as planned. Chat with home, chat with crew, sleep again. DonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get me wrong, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s justÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m starting to feel IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m wasting my life away, just being awake and waiting to get to Eeloo. Cryostasis is starting to look very appealing, but IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve just hit something; an unexplored area of black hole theory. WhatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s inside a black hole? We donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t really know, and we canÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t really find out, and thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s got me intrigued. So, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve started doing some work on that. Yeah, an engineer slash geologist working on black hole theory. Count me in as an honorary astrophysicist.

-----

Chief Engineer/GeologistÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s log, entry 109: IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve left this log far too long, half a year in fact. Too obsessed trying to figure out this black hole stuff. From what I can gather, the information to be gained from this sort of stuff could, hypothetically speaking, enable us to manipulate gravity. Gravity, that ever-so-elusive fundamental force. Now, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m no quantum physicist (though at this rate, I will be), but thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s pretty insane. Gravitational manipulation could open up all sorts of prospects for us as a species. I can think of a couple off the top of my head, sayÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ artificial gravity plating on ships, stations, and bases located on low-mass worlds, uhÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ antigravity vehiclesÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ warp drive. Yeah, warp drive would be coolÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

Just thought of something. Will post another log again at some other time.

-----

Chief Engineer/GeologistÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s log entry 110: Another half year has passed and the equations have piled up everywhere. Nothing else matters. Nothing. This is my work. Mine. I will see it finished. I have spoken with home, just about the only thing keeping me borderline sane. Stasis intermissions, too. The crew are wondering what IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m doing. Only Cal recognised it, and even then he was way out of his depth, he said. Anyway, must work. Work work work. ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s all for me... snack, too, actually.

-----

Chief Engineer/GeologistÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s log, entry 111: Stanley said weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve only a year until Eeloo. Kod, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve done so much to keep myself occupied I hadnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t noticed the passage of time. Everything else is secondary. My work is my life, here. I think IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m onto something, too. Will need to write a paper up at some point. Home is worried IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m going slightly mad. TheyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re probably right.

-----

One year laterÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

A few minutes laterÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re in orbit.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“LetÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s start finalising that, then.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Systems are looking good.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Almost thereÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ wait, throttle stickÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s jammed up a littleÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ I canÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t budge it!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“AGH!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, justÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ caught my thumb. Lengas, you need to look at this ASAP, alright?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“He just went to grab those other papers.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“UghÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ ok, I guess this oneÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s up to me to fix. Bill, how are we looking?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Uh, wellÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ã¢â‚¬Â¦You may want to fix that throttle stick fast.Ã¢â‚¬Â
